stimulus:
Consent Form

Description: Welcome! You are invited to participate in a research study in cognitive psychology. You will be asked to perform various tasks on a computer which may include: looking at images or videos, listening to sounds, reading scenarios, or playing games. You may be asked a number of different questions about making judgments and intepreting people’s actions. All information collected will remain confidential.

Risks and benefits: Risks involved in this study are the same as those normally associated with using a computer (e.g., mild eye/arm strain). If you have any pre-existing conditions that might make reading and completing a computer-based survey strenuous for you, you should probably elect to not participate in this study. If at any time during the study you feel unable to participate because you are experiencing strain, you may end your participation without penalty. We cannot and do not guarantee or promise that you will receive any benefits from this study. Your decision whether or not to participate in this study will not affect your employment, medical care, and/or grades in school.

Time involvement: Your participation in this experiment will take 15 minutes.

Payment: If recruitment materials indicate payment (e.g., Amazon or other recruitment), you will receive compensation as indicated.

Subject's rights: If you have read this notice and have decided to participate in this project, please understand your participation is voluntary and you have the right to withdraw your consent or discontinue participation at any time without penalty or loss of benefits to which you are otherwise entitled. You have the right to refuse to answer particular questions. Your individual privacy will be maintained in all published and written data resulting from the study.

Contact information: If you have any questions, concerns or complaints about this research study, its procedures, or risks and benefits, you should ask the Protocol Director, (Professor Tobias Gerstenberg, Phone: (650) 725-2431; Email: gerstenberg@stanford.edu).

Independent contact: I f you are not satisfied with how this study is being conducted, or if you have any concerns, complaints, or general questions about the research or your rights as a participant, please contact the Stanford Institutional Review Board (IRB) to speak to someone independent of the research team via email at irb2-manager@lists.stanford.edu, or via phone at (650) 723-2480 or toll free at 1-866-680-2906. You can also write to the Stanford IRB, Stanford University, 3000 El Camino Real, Five Palo Alto Square, 4th Floor, Palo Alto, CA 94306.

You may want to print a copy of this consent form to keep. By clicking the button below, you acknowledge that you have read the above information, that you are 18 years of age, or older and give your consent to participate in our internet-based study and consent for us to analyze the resulting data.

Do you agree with the terms of the experiment as explained above?

In this experiment, you will read a few stories. For each story, you will be asked to figure out a missing piece of information

Click the start button whenever you are ready.

Andrew fell over while playing soccer with Kenneth and Robert.
Both Kenneth and Robert stepped on Andrew.

Andrew blamed Kenneth more than Robert for stepping on him.

Who stepped on Andrew by accident?

Carol texted David and Brian to pick her up from the airport.
Neither responded to her text.
Carol later learned that only one of them saw her message.

Carol blamed David more than Brian for not helping.

Who didn't see the text message?

Kimberly needed help moving.
Kimberly asked Jennifer and Dorothy for help, but both said no.
Kimberly wasn't able to move her stuff on her own.

Kimberly blamed Jennifer more than Dorothy for not helping.

Who is Kimberly's closer friend?

Amanda was assigned to do a group project with Ashley and Emily.
Their group did a bad job and received a failing grade for the assignment.

Amanda blamed Ashley more than Emily for the group's failing grade.

Who didn't try very hard on the assignment?

Kevin needed help reaching something on a high shelf.
Kevin asked Donald and John for help, but both said no.
Kevin wasn’t able to reach the item.

Kevin blamed Donald more than John for not helping.

Who is taller?

William had a birthday party.
William asked Joshua and George to come, but neither came.

William blamed Joshua more than George for not coming.

Who is William's closer friend?

Sarah and Barbara each had a birthday party in separate weeks.
Neither invited Betty to the party.
Betty later learned from a friend that one of them intentionally didn't invite her, and another forgot to invite her.

Betty blamed Sarah more than Barbara for not inviting her to her birthday party.

Who forgot to invite Betty?

Matthew needed someone to mow the lawn.
Anthony mowed the lawn.
Karen did not mow the lawn.

Matthew blamed Karen for not mowing the lawn.

Who mowed the lawn?

Lisa needed help practicing for the school play.
Lisa asked Thomas and Mary for help, but both said no.

Lisa blamed Thomas more than Mary for not helping.

Who is Lisa's closer friend?

Susan needed help carrying a very heavy couch.
Susan asked Donna and Steven for help, but both said no.
Susan wasn’t able to move the couch on her own.

Susan blamed Donna more than Steven for not helping.

Who is stronger?

Christopher was on a tug of war team with Charles and Elizabeth.
Their team lost the game of tug of war.

Christopher blamed Charles more than Elizabeth for their loss.

Who tried very hard?

Nancy needed help fixing her flat tire.
Nancy asked Mark and Jessica for help, but neither did.
Nancy didn't manage to fix the tire by herself.

Nancy blamed Mark more than Jessica for not helping.

Who is better at fixing tires?

Richard needed help making dinner.
Neither Michael nor Paul helped.

Richard blamed Michael more than Paul for not helping.

Who knew that Richard needed help making dinner?

Linda needed someone to make an appointment for her.
Linda asked Margaret and Michelle to call and wait on hold for her.
Margaret and Michelle both gave up before their call was picked up.
Linda later learned that one of them waited for a few minutes, and another waited for hours.

Linda blamed Margaret more than Michelle for hanging up.

Who waited for hours before giving up?

Edward, Deborah, and Melissa were having a picnic.
Both Edward and Deborah brought snacks with peanuts in them, even though Melissa was allergic to peanuts.

Melissa blamed Edward more than Deborah for bringing snacks with peanuts to the picnic.

Who didn't know that Melissa was allergic to peanuts?

Joseph always packs himself a lunch to bring to work.
One day, Patricia ate Joseph's lunch.
A different day, Sandra ate Joseph's lunch.

Joseph blamed Patricia more than Sandra for eating his lunch.

Who ate Joseph's lunch on purpose?

Lisa mowed the lawn.
John did not mow the lawn.

Patricia blamed John for not mowing the lawn.

Linda later learned that only one of them saw her message.

Mary blamed Melissa more than Brian for not helping.

Robert blamed Thomas more than Donald for not helping.

Mark asked Charles and Ashley to come, but neither came.
